results.title: Shows promise - should go far (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Deakin, Yorkshire Harlech Television and Michael Tuchner
results.brief_description: A study of four exceptional children in one family. Each child excels in at least one area of learning, eg., mathematics, music, painting. The film looks at the children’s upbringing and its influence on their development. Their mother explains her situation and philosophy underlying her upbringing of the children.

results.title: Shown by request
results.creator_credit: Alexander Shaw, Crown Film Unit and Colin Dean
results.brief_description: Story of 16 mm film use and distribution in Great Britain. Films being used in village hall, in the country, during a factory lunch hour; how the film library works, the procedures in handling a new film and the method of handling requests through all steps until the film has been returned, repaired and put back in the vault.

results.title: Shower = Xizhao
results.creator_credit: Peter Loehr, Imar Film Co, Xi'an Film Studio and Yang Zhang
results.brief_description: This sentimental family drama/comedy from Yang Zhang is set amid the ritualistic world of the Chinese bathhouse and has as its central conflict, family tradition and difference between generations. Da Ming is a businessman, happily ensconced in city ways, who receives a cryptic card from his mentally-handicapped, but exuberant and eternally happy brother, Er Ming. Fearing the worst, Da returns home to find his father contentedly running the local bathhouse, in a decaying neighbourhood of Beijing, and also acting as marriage counsellor and mediator to the many petty quarrels that abound within the male dominated arena. Although urbanised, Da’s ties to the ways of his family and background are rekindled. The bathhouse is more or less a character in itself - it serves as a meeting place for men, especially the elderly, who engage in the bathing practices, including suction cups, massage and shaving, whilst discussing the minutiae of life, and blissfully engaging in ceremonies steeped in old world values, keeping the time-pressed pace of modernisation at bay. At times the tone of the film is cloying, but the overall impression is one of a lilting comedy that speaks of China’s contemporary cultural issues examined within the experience of one small family. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Showbiz ballyhoo
results.creator_credit: T A D Productions, Richard Gabourie Productions, Norman Sedawie and Gail Gibson Sedawie
results.brief_description: This documentary examines the machinations and power of the Hollywood studio publicity departments of the 1930s and 40s, a time of the studios’ heyday, when the public had an unbridled fascination for the stars of the silver screen. On screen and off, fans were sold the notion of the dream, where glamour, money, fame and beauty were in endless supply. Movie newsreels, gossip columnists and press agents played a major role in presenting actors such as Errol Flynn, Clarke Gable and Vivien Leigh as eternally glamorous and gay, spending their lives at parties and opening night galas. Actors, celebrities and child stars were also used as a propaganda tool, sending messages that supported various causes, including war bonds, bills of government and political parties. Public appearances were as important as the films that the stars made, and actors were expected to tour on junkets around the country. Footage in the documentary includes clips from iconic Hollywood films, famous screen tests, bloopers and scenes from spectacular musical productions of the 1930s. Features footage of: Humphrey Bogart, Bette Davis, Joan Crawford, Bing Crosby, James Cagney, Shirley Temple, Mickey Rooney, Judy Garland, Ronald Reagan, Rita Hayworth, Tyrone Power and The Marx Brothers.

results.title: Show me what you look like
results.creator_credit: Michael Whitehead, IKON (GB) and Brian Nicholson
results.brief_description: This is an experimental video. Sound and image do not necessarily correspond. The video moves from realist observation of everyday life to bizarre and surreal flights of fancy. “Show Me What You Look Like” is part of an alternative film and video culture which disregards mainstream concerns with narrative, commerce and exposition, and instead is committed to the production of cultural material which is personal, challenging and down-right weird. The electronic music score is by the English band Durutti Column.

results.title: Show girls
results.creator_credit: Meilan Lam, Barrie Angus McLean, David Verrall, Tamara Lynch and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Show Girls’ celebrates Montreal’s swinging Black jazz scene from the 1920’s to the 1960’s, when the city was wide open. Three women who danced in the legendary Black clubs of the day - Rockhead’s Paradise, The Terminal, Cafe St. Michel - share their unforgettable memories of life at the center of one of the world’s hottest jazz spots. From the Roaring Twenties, through the Second World War, and on into the golden era of clubs in the fifties and sixties, ‘Show Girls’ chronicles the lives of Bernice, Tina and Olga, mixing their memories with rarely seen footage of the era. Their stories are told against a backdrop of the fascinating social and political history that made Montreal a jazz and nightclub hotspot for decades. It is a story of song and dance, music and pride. (Award: Yorkton.) Narrated by Anthony Sherwood.

results.title: Show business
results.creator_credit: Eddie Cantor, RKO Radio Pictures and Edwin Marin
results.brief_description: Show business follows the fortunes of a small group of stage folk from 1914 to 1929 and is based on incidents from Eddie Cantor’s life. Features scenes from a variety of performers including minstrel shows, vaudeville, Grand Opera and Ziegfeld Follies. Songs include “You may not remenber me”, “It had to be you” and “Whoopee” Cast includes Eddie Cantor, Joan Davis, George Murphy and Constance Moore. Story by Bert Granet.

results.title: Shout! the story of Johnny O'keefe
results.brief_description: Johnny O’Keefe, the man who almost single-handedly created the Australian rock`n’roll industry. The man who challenged the Americans and broke all the rules, and whose reward was the devotion of millions of fans for a generation. This is the true story - all the triumphs and all the tears that drove the man forward and ultimately to his tragic, untimely death in 1978. A must for everyone who was there.

results.title: Shout it out numbers
results.brief_description: Uses animated geometric shapes and music to illustrate numbers from one to ten. Triangles, circles, and squares transform into animals, trains, suns, see-saws and other familiar objects.
